title: Host Header is not validated resulting in Open Redirect

activities.message:
Thanks for reporting this.

It appears this is only an issue for POST requests which redirect on success. Because these redirects are always with a 302 status, they will not be cached by browsers. Additionally, as we now use CSRF tokens on all POST requests, it would not be possible to  trigger this redirect from a third-party site.

Please let me know if any of these statements are incorrect.

We may still award a bounty for this issue as it is certainly undesired behaviour, but I don't believe it constitutes a security risk.

activities.message:
This is not an issue only for POST requests. It applies to GET requests as well. See attached pic. It might also apply to PUT, DELETE requests if there exists such methods in the application. 

I am not sure I understand your reasoning of 302 status and not caching. An attacker can simply send the wrong host in the requests and poison the cache of proxies/web server. It has nothing to do with the browser's cache. 

Next time, a legitimate user tries to access the correct host but since the cache of the web server is poisoned with the attacker's domain, the legitimate user will be redirected to the attacker's domain. 

Again, there is no need for CSRF tokens to prevent it from redirecting legitimate users. As seen in the new pic, it affects the first request itself where there is no CSRF token. 

I agree that exploiting this is not trivial. It depends on a few factors like the web server and the way it interprets the host header, the ability of attackers to poison the cache, etc. And, it should definitely be fixed.

vulnerability_information_html:
Please see the attached screenshot where I am sending a request to irccloud.com with an invalid HOST header and I am getting redirected to that domain. This is because the HOST header is not validated to ensure that the request is originating from that target host or not.

http://www.skeletonscribe.net/2013/05/practical-http-host-header-attacks.html http://carlos.bueno.org/2008/06/host-header-injection.html
The above links mention 2 different ways to exploit this issue:

  1. web-cache poisoning and/or
  2. Using alternate channels like password reset emails.

For the first way, it can be exploited by poisoning a cache with the attacker's domain and then serving that poisoned response to legitimate users, causing them to redirect to the attacker's domain. This attack kind of varies depending on different web servers as they interpret duplicate Host headers in different ways. The attack vectors are very well explained in the above blogs so I don't want to re-iterate them here again.

For the second way, I verified that the password reset functionality on the IRC Cloud website does not retrieve the Host header when sending emails. But, validating the Host header is always a good practice.
